# 
# 
Heart-healthy meal planning includes:

Limiting unhealthy fats.   
Increasing healthy fats.   
Making other small dietary changes. 
You may need to talk with your doctor or a diet specialist (dietitian) to create an eating plan that is right for you. 
# 
· Choose healthy fats. These include olive oil and canola oil, flaxseeds, walnuts, almonds, and seed · Eat more omega-3 fats. These include salmon, mackerel, sardines, tuna, flaxseed oil, and ground flaxseeds. Try to eat fish at least twice each week.   
· Limit saturated fats.   
° Saturated fats are often found in animal products, such as meats, butter, and cream.   
。 Plant sources of saturated fats include palm oil, palm kernel oil, and coconut oil.   
$\bullet$ Avoid foods with partially hydrogenated oils in them. These include stick margarine, some tub margarines, cookies, crackers, and other baked goods. These contain trans fats. 
# 
· Check food labels carefully. Identify foods with trans fats or high amounts of saturated fat.   
· Fill one half of your plate with vegetables and green salads. Eat 4-5 servings of vegetables per day.   
serving of vegetables is: 。 1 cup of raw leafy vegetables.   
$0\%$ cup of raw or cooked cut-up vegetables.   
。 $\%$ cup of vegetable juice.   
· Fill one fourth of your plate with whole grains. Look for the word "whole" as the first word in the ingredient list.   
· Fill one fourth of your plate with lean protein foods.   
· Eat 4-5 servings of fruit per day. A serving of fruit is: 。 One medium whole fruit.   
。 $\%$ cup of dried fruit.   
。 $\%$ cup of fresh, frozen, or canned fruit.   
。 $\%$ cup of $100\%$ fruit juice.   
· Eat more foods that contain soluble fiber. These include apples, broccoli, carrots, beans, peas, and barley. Try to get $ 20{-}30~\mathrm{g}$ of fiber per day.   
· Eat more home-cooked food. Eat less restaurant, buffet, and fast food.   
· Limit or avoid alcohol.   
· Limit foods high in starch and sugar.   
$\bullet$ Avoid fried foods. · Avoid frying your food. Try baking, boiling, grilling, or broiling it instead. You can also reduce fat by: 。 Removing the skin from poultry.   
。 Removing all visible fats from meats.   
° Skimming the fat off of stews, soups, and gravies before serving them.   
。 Steaming vegetables in water or broth.   
· Lose weight if you are overweight.   
· Eat 4-5 servings of nuts, legumes, and seeds per week:   
。 One serving of dried beans or legumes equals $\%$ cup after being cooked.   
。 One serving of nuts equals $1\%$ ounces.   
。 One serving of seeds equals $\%$ ounce or one tablespoon.   
· You may need to keep track of how much salt or sodium you eat. This is especially true if you have high blood pressure. Talk with your doctor or dietitian to get more information.

# 
Grains 
Breads, including French, white, pita, wheat, raisin, rye, oatmeal, and Italian. Tortillas that are neither fried nor made with lard or trans fat. Low-fat rolls, including hotdog and hamburger buns and English muffins. Biscuits. Muffins. Waffles. Pancakes. Light popcorn. Whole-grain cereals. Flatbread. Melba toast. Pretzels. Breadsticks. Rusks. Low-fat snacks. Low-fat crackers, including oyster, saltine, matzo, graham, animal, and rye. Rice and pasta, including brown rice and pastas that are made with whole wheat. 
Vegetables 
All vegetables. 
Fruits 
All fruits, but limit coconut. 
Meats and Other Protein Sources 
Lean, well-trimmed beef, veal, pork, and lamb. Chicken and turkey without skin. All fish and shellfish. Wild duck, rabbit, pheasant, and venison. Egg whites or low-cholesterol egg substitutes. Dried beans, peas, lentils, and tofu. Seeds and most nuts. 
Dairy 
Low-fat or nonfat cheeses, including ricotta, string, and mozzarella. Skim or $1\%$ milk that is liquid, powdered, or evaporated. Buttermilk that is made with low-fat milk. Nonfat or low-fat yogurt. 
Beverages 
Mineral water. Diet carbonated beverages. 
Sweets and Desserts 
Sherbets and fruit ices. Honey, jam, marmalade, jelly, and syrups. Meringues and gelatins. Pure sugar candy, such as hard candy, jelly beans, gumdrops, mints, marshmallows, and small amounts of dark chocolate.Angel foodcake. 
Eat all sweets and desserts in moderation. 
Fats and Oils 
Nonhydrogenated (trans-free) margarines. Vegetable oils, including soybean, sesame, sunflower, olive, peanut, safflower, corn, canola, and cottonseed. Salad dressings or mayonnaise made with a vegetable Name:ARTHUS,GERARDA   
MRN:(RMC)-031064241

oil. Limit added fats and oils that you use for cooking, baking, salads, and as spreads. 
Other 
Cocoa powder. Coffee and tea. All seasonings and condiments. 
The items listed above may not be a complete list of recommended foods or beverages. Contact your dietitianformoreoptions. 
# 
Grains 
Breads that are made with saturated or trans fats, oils, or whole milk. Croissants. Butter rolls. Cheese breads. Sweet rolls. Donuts. Buttered popcorn. Chow mein noodles. High-fat crackers, such as cheese Orbuttercrackers. 
# 
Fatty meats, such as hotdogs, short ribs, sausage, spareribs, bacon, rib eye roast or steak, and mutton. High-fat deli meats, such as salami and bologna. Caviar. Domestic duck and goose. Organ meats, such as kidney, liver, sweetbreads, and heart. 
# 
Cream, sour cream, cream cheese, and creamed cottage cheese. Whole-milk cheeses, including blue (blen), Monterey Jack, Brie, Colby, American, Havarti, Swiss, cheddar, Camembert, and Muenster. Wholeor $2\%$ milk that is liquid, evaporated, or condensed. Whole buttermilk. Cream sauce or high-fat cheese sauce. Yogurt that is made from whole milk. 
Beverages 
Regular sodas and juice drinks with added sugar. 
Sweets and Desserts 
Frosting. Pudding. Cookies. Cakes other than angel food cake. Candy that has milk chocolate or white chocolate, hydrogenated fat, butter, coconut, or unknown ingredients. Buttered syrups. Full-fat ice cream or ice cream drinks. 
# 
Gravy that has suet, meat fat, or shortening. Cocoa butter, hydrogenated oils, palm oil, coconut oil, palm kernel oil. These can often be found in baked products, candy, fried foods, nondairy creamers, and whipped toppings. Solid fats and shortenings, including bacon fat, salt pork, lard, and butter. Nondairy cream substitutes, such as coffee creamers and sour cream substitutes. Salad dressings that are made of unknown oils, cheese, or sour cream. 
The items listed above nay not be a complete list of foods and beverages to avoid. Contact your dietitianformore information. 
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.

A heart attack (myocardial infarction, MI) causes damage to the heart that cannot be fixed. A heart attack often happens when a blood clot or other blockage cuts blood flow to the heart. When this happens, certain areas of the heart begin to die. This causes the pain you feel during a heart attack. 

# 
· Take medicine as told by your doctor. You may need medicine to:   
. Keep your blood from clotting too easily.   
. Control your blood pressure.   
。 Lower your cholesterol.   
Control abnormal heart rhythms. Change certain behaviors as told by your doctor. This may include: Quitting smoking. Being active. Eating a heart-healthy diet. Ask your doctor for help with this diet.   
. Keeping a healthy weight.   
· Keeping your diabetes under control.   
. Lessening stress.   
° Limiting how much alcohol you drink. 
Do not take these medicines unless your doctor says that you can: 
· Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). These include: 。lbuprofen.   
·Naproxen.   
.Celecoxib.   
· Vitamin supplements that have vitamin A, vitamin E, or both.   
· Hormone therapy that contains estrogen with or without progestin. 
# 
. You have sudden chest discomfort.   
.You have sudden discomfort in your: 。Arms.   
。Back.   
·Neck.

Jaw. 
You have shortness of breath at any time.   
.You have sudden sweating or clammy skin.   
· You feel sick to your stomach (nauseous) or throw up (vomit).   
You suddenly get light-headed or dizzy.   
· You feel your heart beating fast or skipping beats. 
These symptoms may be an emergency. Do not wait to see if the symptoms will go away. Get medical help right away. Call your local emergency services (911 in the U.S.). Do not drive yourself to the hospital. 
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.

# 
Hypertension is another name for high blood pressure. High blood pressure forces your heart to work harder to pump blood. A blood pressure reading has two numbers, which includes a higher number over a lower number (example: 110/72). 

# 
· Have your blood pressure rechecked by your doctor.   
· Only take medicine as told by your doctor. Follow the directions carefully. The medicine does not work as well if you skip doses. Skipping doses also puts you at risk for problems.   
$\bullet$ Do notsmoke.   
· Monitor your blood pressure at home as told by your doctor. 
# 
. You think you are having a reaction to the medicine you are taking.   
You have repeat headaches or feel dizzy.   
·You have puffiness (swelling) in your ankles.   
·You have trouble with your vision.

# 
. You get a very bad headache and are confused.   
You feel weak, numb, or faint.   
. You get chest or belly (abdominal) pain.   
·You throw up (vomit).   
·You cannot breathe very well. 
#

·Will watch your condition. Will get help right away if you are not doing well or get worse. 
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.

# 
Coronary artery disease (CAD) is a process in which the blood vessels of the heart (coronary arteries) become narrow or blocked. The narrowing or blockage can lead to decreased blood flow to the heart muscle (angina). Prolonged reduced blood flow can cause a heart attack (myocardial infarction, MI). Because CAD is the leading cause of death in men, it is important to understand what causes this condition and how it is treated. 
# 
Atherosclerosis is the cause of CAD. This is the buildup of fat and cholesterol (plaque) on the inside of the arteries. Over time, the plaque may narrow or block the artery, and this will lessen blood flow to the heart. Plaque can also become weak and break off within a coronary artery to form a clot and cause a suddenblockage. 
# 
Many risk factors increase your chances of getting CAD, including: 
High cholesterol levels.   
High blood pressure (hypertension).   
· Tobacco use.   
· Diabetes.   
Age. Men over age 45 are at a greater risk of CAD.   
Gender. Men often develop CAD earlier in life than women.   
Family history of CAD.   
Obesity.   
Lack of exercise.   
·A diet high in saturated fats. 
# 
Many people do not experience any symptoms during the early stages of CAD. As the condition   
Name:ARTHUS,GERARD A   
MMDNI:RMCL031064241   
FIN:016210755-7314

progresses, symptoms may include: 
. Chest pain.   
° The pain can be described as a crushing or squeezing in the chest, or a tightness, pressure, fullness, or heaviness in the chest.   
° The pain can last more than a few minutes or can stop and recur.   
· Pain in the arms, neck, jaw, or back.   
· Unexplained heartburn or indigestion.   
· Shortness of breath.   
· Nausea.   
·. Sudden cold sweats. 
Less common symptoms of CAD in men can include: 
·Fatigue.   
Unexplained feelings of nervousness or anxiety.   
·Weakness.   
· Diarrhea.   
· Sudden light-headedness. 
# 
Tests to diagnose CAD may include? 
·ECG (electrocardiogram).   
· Exercise stress test. This looks for signs of blockage when the heart is being exercised.   
· Pharmacologic stress test. This test looks for signs of blockage when the heart is being stressed with a medicine.   
·Blood tests.   
· Coronary angiogram. This is a procedure to look at the coronary arteries to see if there is any blockage. 
# 
The treatment of CAD may include the following: 
· Healthy behavioral changes to reduce or control risk factors.   
·Medicine.   
· Coronary stenting. A stent helps to keep an artery open.   
· Coronary angioplasty. This procedure widens a narrowed or blocked artery.   
· Coronary artery bypass surgery. This will allow your blood to pass the blockage (bypass) to reach your heart. 
# 
· Take medicines only as directed by your health care provider.   
$\bullet$ Do not take the following medicines unless your health care provider approves:   
o Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen, naproxen, or celecoxib. o Vitamin supplements that contain vitamin A, vitamin E, or both.   
· Manage other health conditions such as hypertension and diabetes as directed by your health care provider. · Follow a heart-healthy diet. A dietitian can help to educate you about healthy food options and changes.   
. Use healthy cooking methods such as roasting, grilling, broiling, baking, poaching, steaming, or stir-frying. Talk to a dietitian to learn more about healthy cooking methods.   
· Follow an exercise program approved by your health care provider.   
· Maintain a healthy weight. Lose weight as approved by your health care provider.   
· Plan rest periods when fatigued.   
· Learn to manage stress.   
· Do not use any tobacco products, including cigarettes, chewing tobacco, or electronic cigarettes. If you need help quitting, ask your health care provider.   
· If you drink alcohol, and your health care provider approves, limit your alcohol intake to no more than 1 drink per day. One drink equals 12 ounces of beer, 5 ounces of wine, or $1\%$ ounces of hard liquor. · Stop illegal drug use.   
· Your health care provider may ask you to monitor your blood pressure. A blood pressure reading consists of a higher number over a lower number, such as 110 over 72, which is written as 110/72. Ideally, your blood pressure should be:   
? Below 140/90 if you have no other medical conditions.   
. Below 130/80 if you have diabetes or kidney disease.   
· Keep all follow-up visits as directed by your health care provider. This is important.

# 
. You have pain in your chest, neck, arm, jaw, stomach, or back that lasts more than a few minutes, is recurring, or is unrelieved by taking medicine under your tongue (sublingual nitroglycerin).   
· You have profuse sweating without cause.   
· You have unexplained: · Heartburn or indigestion.   
Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing.   
。 Nausea or vomiting.   
。 Fatigue.   
。 Feelings of nervousness or anxiety.   
。Weakness.   
· Diarrhea.   
· You have sudden light-headedness or dizziness.   
·You faint. 
These symptoms may represent a serious problem that is an emergency. Do not wait to see if the symptoms will go away. Get medical help right away. Call your local emergency services (911 in the U.s.). Do not drive yourself to the hospital. 
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider. 
# 
Angina pectoris is a very bad feeling in the chest, neck, or arm. Your doctor may call it angina. There are four types of angina. Angina is caused by a lack of blood in the middle and thickest layer of the heart wall (myocardium). Angina may feel like a crushing or squeezing pain in the chest. It may feel like tightness or heavy pressure in the chest. Some people say it feels like gas, heartburn, or indigestion. Some people have symptoms other than pain. These include:

· Shortness of breath.   
· Cold sweats.   
· Feeling sick to your stomach (nausea).   
·Feeling light-headed. 
Many women have chest discomfort and some of the other symptoms. However, women often have different symptoms, such as: 
·Feeling tired (fatigue).   
· Feeling nervous for no reason.   
Feeling weak for no reason.   
· Dizziness or fainting. 
Women may have angina without any symptoms. 
# 
· Take medicines only as told by your doctor.   
· Take care of other health issues as told by your doctor. These include: 。 High blood pressure (lhypertension).   
· Diabetes.   
· Follow a heart-healthy diet. Your doctor can help you to choose healthy food options and make changes.   
· Talk to your doctor to learn more about healthy cooking methods and use them. These include: ·Roasting.   
Grilling.   
。Broiling.   
· Baking.   
。 Poaching.   
·Steaming.   
。 Stir-frying.   
· Follow an exercise program approved by your doctor.   
$\bullet$ Keep a healthy weight. Lose weight as told by your doctor. · Rest when you are tired.   
· Learn to manage stress.   
· Do not use any tobacco, such as cigarettes, chewing tobacco, or electronic cigarettes. If you need help quitting, ask your doctor.   
· If you drink alcohol, and your doctor says it is okay, limit yourself to no more than 1 drink per day.   
One drink equals 12 ounces of beer, 5 ounces of wine, or $1\%$ ounces of hard liquor.   
· Stop illegal drug use.   
· Keep all follow-up visits as told by your doctor. This is important.

Do not take these medicines unless your doctor says that you can: 
· Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). These include: ·Ibuprofen.   
Naproxen.   
Celecoxib.   
· Vitamin supplements that have vitamin A, vitamin E, or both.   
· Hormone therapy that contains estrogen with or without progestin. 
# 
. You have pain in your chest, neck, arm, jaw, stomach, or back that: Lasts more than a few minutes.   
· Comes back.   
° Does not get better after you take medicine under your tongue (sublingual nitroglycerin).   
· You have any of these symptoms for no reason: 。 Gas, heartburn, or indigestion.   
. Sweating a lot.   
。 Shortness of breath or trouble breathing.   
° Feeling sick to your stomach or throwing up.   
o Feeling more tired than usual.   
o Feeling nervous or worrying more than usual.   
。 Feeling weak.   
。 Diarrhea.   
. You are suddenly dizzy or light-headed.   
. You faint or pass out. 
These symptoms may be an emergency. Do not wait to see if the symptoms will go away. Get medical help right away. Call your local emergency services (911 in the U.s.). Do not drive yourself to the hospital. 
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
